title: How does a self-published author combat book piracy? - Quora

response.answer_text: The best way to combat book piracy is to never release the PDF files from which they are printed. Once these files are sent to the Copyright Office or to the Library of Congress, for example, they are available for FREE upon request by anyone. We can thank the Freedom of Information Act for this government-sanctioned release of our long, hard, private work, rather than protecting it. Send print copies, instead. Few pirates want to go to the trouble of paying for individual page copies or scanned pages of these books from government agencies . However, traditionally-published books also are pirated. There is no sure bet. Getting priated copies taken down largely requires the time-consuming, costly effort of professionals assigned exclusively to this task. It is virtually impossible to deal with this myriad of pirates. Sites offering “free” merchandise often are quite popular. “Free” merchandise generates traffic, which improves site rankings. The owner actually pays the price, with potential loss of sales/royalties. However, a click on these offerings may be malware bait for the person in search of “freebies”. I hope this answers your question. Best wishes.

There’s very little you can do about it. Sure, you can threaten them with taking legal action, but very few people have the time or the cash to chase down every website or pirate that’s going to offer your book for free. - The major movie studios have tried that and haven’t had any success doing it. The thing you’ve got to keep in mind is that anyone that’s going to rob a copy of your book from an illegal site, was never going to pay for your work, or anyone’s for that matter. (That’s why they hang out on pirate sites.) - So they’re the worst fans you can have. If they’re not willing to support you and your craft, they’re not worth a minute of your time. Focus instead on the people who do support you, and focus all you time and effort there. Anything else is going to rob time that you could be focusing on your business. - I know this only too well, after having some of my digital training courses robbed and sent to every corner of the Internet.
